title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: 1 Assignment 1
text:
P_S <- 0.3 P_not_S <- 0.7
P_T_given_S <- 0.2 P_not_T_given_S <- 0.8
P_T_given_not_S <- 0.6 P_not_T_given_not_S <- 0.4



P_T_and_S <- P_S * P_T_given_S P_T_and_not_S <- P_not_S * P_T_given_not_S P_not_T_and_S <- P_S * P_not_T_given_S P_not_T_and_not_S <- P_not_S * P_not_T_given_not_S



sum_of_probabilities <- P_T_and_S + P_T_and_not_S + P_not_T_and_S + P_not_T_and_not_S



cat(“P(T ∩ S):”, P_T_and_S, “”) cat(“P(T ∩ ~S):”, P_T_and_not_S, “”) cat(“P(~T ∩ S):”, P_not_T_and_S, “”) cat(“P(~T ∩ ~S):”, P_not_T_and_not_S, “”) cat(“Sum of all four probabilities:”, sum_of_probabilities, “”)

title: 1 Assignment 1
text:
P_S <- 0.3 P_not_S <- 0.7
P_T_given_S <- 0.2 P_not_T_given_S <- 0.8
P_T_given_not_S <- 0.6 P_not_T_given_not_S <- 0.4

title: 1 Assignment 1
text:
2.1 From Diagram Venn
library(knitr) image_url <- “https://owmork.github.io/causal_ds/content/fundamentals/01_a_prob_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png” include_graphics(image_url)

title: 1 Assignment 1
section: 2.2 Replace the URL with the actual URL of the image
text:
2.2 Replace the URL with the actual URL of the image
image_url <- “https://owmork.github.io/causal_ds/content/fundamentals/01_a_prob_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png”

title: 1 Assignment 1
text:
2.3 Include the image using knitr::include_graphics
include_graphics(image_url)

title: 1 Assignment 1
text:
2.2 Given data
all_three_devices <- 5 at_least_two_devices <- 73+33+88 only_one_device <- 278+423+100

title: 1 Assignment 1
text:
2.4 Calculate percentages
percentage_all_three_devices <- (all_three_devices / total_customers) * 100 percentage_at_least_two_devices <- (at_least_two_devices / total_customers) * 100 percentage_only_one_device <- (only_one_device / total_customers) * 100

title: 1 Assignment 1
text:
2.5 Print the results
cat(“Percentage of customers using all three devices:”, percentage_all_three_devices, “%”) cat(“Percentage of customers using at least two devices:”, percentage_at_least_two_devices, “%”) cat(“Percentage of customers using only one device:”, percentage_only_one_device, “%”)

title: 1 Assignment 1
text:
2.3 Total number of customers
total_customers <- all_three_devices + at_least_two_devices + only_one_device

title: 1 Assignment 1
text:
3.1 Given probabilities
P_Alarm_given_Faulty_prod <- 0.97 P_Alarm_given_not_Faulty_prod <- 0.01 P_Faulty_prod <- 0.04 P_not_Faulty_prod <- 1 - P_Faulty_prod

P_Alarm <- P_Alarm_given_Faulty_prod * P_Faulty_prod + P_Alarm_given_not_Faulty_prod * P_not_Faulty_prod

P_not_Faulty_prod_given_Alarm <- (P_Alarm_given_not_Faulty_prod * P_not_Faulty_prod) / P_Alarm

P_Faulty_prod_given_Alarm <- (P_Alarm_given_Faulty_prod * P_Faulty_prod) / P_Alarm

title: 1 Assignment 1
text:
3.2 Calculate P(Alarm)
P_Alarm <- P_Alarm_given_Faulty_prod * P_Faulty_prod + P_Alarm_given_not_Faulty_prod * P_not_Faulty_prod

title: 1 Assignment 1
section: 3.2 Calculate P(~Faulty_prod | Alarm) using Bayes’ Theorem
text:
3.2 Calculate P(~Faulty_prod | Alarm) using Bayes’ Theorem
P_not_Faulty_prod_given_Alarm <- (P_Alarm_given_not_Faulty_prod * P_not_Faulty_prod) / P_Alarm

title: 1 Assignment 1
section: 3.3 Calculate P(Faulty_prod | Alarm) using Bayes’ Theorem
text:
3.3 Calculate P(Faulty_prod | Alarm) using Bayes’ Theorem
P_Faulty_prod_given_Alarm <- (P_Alarm_given_Faulty_prod * P_Faulty_prod) / P_Alarm

title: 1 Assignment 1
text:
3.2 Print the results
cat(“a. P(~Faulty_prod | Alarm):”, P_not_Faulty_prod_given_Alarm, “”) cat(“b. P(Faulty_prod | Alarm):”, P_Faulty_prod_given_Alarm, “”)

title: 1 Assignment 1
section: 3.3 Fill in the gaps in the sentence
text:
3.3 Fill in the gaps in the sentence
percentage_not_Faulty_prod_given_Alarm <- round(P_not_Faulty_prod_given_Alarm * 100, 2) percentage_Faulty_prod_given_Alarm <- round(P_Faulty_prod_given_Alarm * 100, 2)
cat(“These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about”, percentage_not_Faulty_prod_given_Alarm, “% that the product is flawless and a probability of”, percentage_Faulty_prod_given_Alarm, “% that the product is faulty.”, “”)
